title: Local Governments Try to Regulate Guns With High Tax
content:
Tacoma , Wash. , could soon become one of a handful of U.S. cities to levy high taxes on gun sales , opening a new front in the battle over how much power local governments have to regulate firearms .
Washington and 44 other states ban cities and towns from making their own gun laws . But the proposed tax in Tacoma , which would collect $ 25 per gun sale to fund violence prevention programs , is modeled on a law in neighboring Seattle that has already passed muster with the state supreme court .
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS How do you think this tax would affect residents and businesses of Tacoma ? Join the conversation below .
“ I can ’ t ban assault rifles in the city of Tacoma . I can ’ t ban certain types of ammo in the city of Tacoma . I can ’ t require safe storage . There ’ s a lot I can ’ t do , ” said Ryan Mello , the Tacoma councilman behind the measure . “ The one thing I am not pre-empted from doing is reasonable taxation on firearms and ammunition . ”
Opponents of the proposal , which would also collect taxes on ammunition , have said it would force gun shops out of the industrial port city of 215,000 . In Seattle , lawmakers projected $ 300,000 to $ 500,000 a year in gun taxes , but last year received only $ 77,642 because gun stores moved away .
“ It ’ ll put us out of business ; there ’ s no ifs , ands or buts about it , ” said Dan Davies , who owns Mary ’ s Pistols in Tacoma with his wife Mary Davies . “ They ’ re punishing innocent people for the deeds of criminals . ”
The largest pro-gun groups in the country are fighting against the Tacoma tax , which is scheduled for a city council vote on Tuesday . Lawrence Keane , senior vice president of government relations and public affairs for the National Shooting Sports Foundation , the firearms-industry trade association , said he worries that other cities could follow in Tacoma ’ s footsteps .
“ Are we concerned that politicians will try to seek their antigun agenda through taxation ? ” said Mr. Keane . “ Yes , that ’ s what this is about . ”
Last week , a gun parts maker called Aero Precision , which employs around 400 people in Tacoma , issued a statement saying it opposes the tax and “ will be forced to explore our options if the Tacoma City Council does vote this in to place . ”
Sergey Solyanik moved his gun store , Precise Shooter , from Seattle to neighboring Lynnwood because he said customers would just travel outside of the city where prices are lower . “ It ’ s not really possible to run a store with this tax , ” he said .
Mr. Mello , the councilman behind the Tacoma measure , said he doesn ’ t fear such threats and predicts that the tax will bring in between $ 30,000 and $ 40,000 each year to fund violence prevention programs while making buying a gun less appealing .
Many states over the past four decades , and largely at the urging of the National Rifle Association , have passed so-called gun pre-emption laws , or laws that limit locals ’ authority to regulate guns . The NRA has argued that they help gun owners avoid a patchwork of laws . Cities across the country have tried to buck these prohibitions with little success .
Pittsburgh earlier this year passed restrictions on semiautomatic rifles like the AR-15 model used in a 2018 mass shooting at a synagogue in that city . The law was immediately met with a lawsuit filed with the backing of the NRA and has since been put on hold .
Last week , a Washington state judge ruled that Edmonds , a municipality north of Seattle , can ’ t enforce a new city law requiring gun owners to keep their guns locked up at home . The decision came in response to a legal challenge from the NRA and the Second Amendment Foundation , which is based in Washington state .
Cook County in Illinois , which is home to Chicago , passed a gun tax in 2013 , and Seattle followed in 2015 . Tim Burgess , a former Seattle city council member , said he came up with the tax as a way to pay for a gun violence research and prevention program at a local hospital , Harborview Medical Center . “ Let ’ s tax the firearms industry because it ’ s their product that ’ s causing this harm , ” said Mr. Burgess .
In 2017 , the state supreme court ruled in favor of Seattle and against the NRA , the NSSF and the Second Amendment Foundation , writing that the tax ’ s primary purpose is not to regulate firearms but “ to raise revenue for the public benefit . ”
